Improved catalytic performance of acid-activated sepiolite supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts for liquid phase hydrogenation of 1,6-hexanedinitrile Yang Lv a b Fang Hao a ⁎ Pingle Liu a b ⁎ Shaofeng Xiong a He’an Luo a b a College of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, China College of Chemical Engineering Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 China b National & Local United Engineering Research Centre for Chemical Process Simulation and Intensification, Xiangtan University, China National & Local United Engineering Research Centre for Chemical Process Simulation and Intensification Xiangtan University China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: College of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, China. College of Chemical Engineering Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 China Graphical abstract Different inorganic acids were used to activate sepiolite, and the acid-activated sepiolites supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts were prepared. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption, hydrogen chemisorption, ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) were used to characterize the catalysts. The catalytic performance of the acid-activated sepiolite supported K-Ni bimetallic catalysts were investigated in 1,6-hexanedinitrile (HDN) hydrogenation in liquid phase. It was revealed that the potassium could increase the alkalinity of the catalyst with the aim of inhibiting the formation of the 1-azacycloheptane (ACH). And the addition of potassium reduces the particle size of nickel and improves its dispersion. Compared with hydrochloric acid and sulfuric acid, nitric acid treatment increases more silanol groups (SiOH) on the sepiolite surface, which is helpful to nickel particles adsorption and dispersion. Nitric acid activated sepiolite supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts (K-Ni/NASEP) present the best catalytic performance, the conversion of HDN comes up to 92.0% under moderate conditions of lower temperature and pressure, the selectivity to 6-aminocapronitrile (ACN) and 1,6-hexanediamine (HDA) is up to 95.2%. Keywords 1,6-Hexanedinitrile Hydrogenation 6-Aminocapronitrile 1,6-Hexanediamine Acid-activated sepiolites supported catalyst 1 Introduction Nylon-6 fibers and resins are manufactured from ε-caprolactam (CPL), an important petrochemical materials. The problem for the production of ε-caprolactam mainly lies in its complicated process and a great deal of by-product of ammonium sulfate [1]. Recently, researchers are developing new methods to obtain ε-caprolactam at lower cost and less environmental pollution. In comparison to the current ketone-hydroxylamine processes, the route of butadiene hydrocyanation for ε-caprolactam production has such advantages, it involves the synthesis of 1,6-hexanedinitrile (HDN), HDN hydrogenation to 6-aminocapronitrile (ACN) and ACN cyclization to ε-caprolactam in water [2–4]. Among these steps, HDN hydrogenation to ACN is the critical step in this novel route, 1,6-hexanediamine (HDA) and Schiff bases are the deep hydrogenation products [4]. Moreover, HDA is an significant industrial intermediate mainly applied to produce nylon-66 [2,5]. Researchers have tried HDN hydrogenation either in gas or liquid phase [6–12]. Nickel-based amorphous catalysts have shown higher catalytic performance in various hydrogenation processes [13,14]. However, the poor thermal stability limits its application in industry. For instance, Hexing Li et al. [15,16] have studied the effects of amorphous Ni-P and Ni-B for HDN hydrogenation in gas phase under higher temperature and space velocity, and the selectivity to ACN is as low as 30% and HDA is the main product. The HDN hydrogenation in gas phase over Ni-MgO catalysts was recently reported by Serra et al. [6–8]. Although these catalysts exhibited better catalytic performance of 87% HDN conversion and 83% selectivity to ACN, the process was carried out at space velocity of 7162h−1, 473K and high consumption of hydrogen. The characterization and activities of several potassium-doped nickel, alumina-supported nickel catalysts and iron-nickel catalysts in HDN hydrogenation have been investigated by Medina et al. [17–20]. As to HDN hydrogenation in liquid phase catalyzed by Raney Ni or Co in ammonia or alkali metal hydroxide solution at high pressure [21–26], Raney Ni or Co are very active, however, they are pyrophoric and hard to divide from the process fluid. Moreover, a large quantity of ammonia is necessary to impede side reactions leading to the conformation of secondary and tertiary amines. It has been reported that it is helpful to improve the selectivity to ACN by surface modification of the catalyst [10,11,17,19,20,27], and the additives and the supported metal type has great effects on the activity of the nickel catalysts [11,15–17,19,20,27]. Sepiolite is a kind of fibrous clay material with the chemical formula of Mg8Si12O30(OH)4(OH2)4·nH2O and open porous framework [28–30]. Due to its peculiar structure and broad distribution in nature, sepiolite is widely used as catalyst support [28,30]. Recently, researchers pay much attention to active sepiolite by various surface modification methods in order to improve the adsorptivity of sepiolite [31]. During the acid activation process, the magnesium ions located in octahedral layers are dissolved and the tetrahedral silicate sheets are retained and then the sepiolite changes into amorphous silica and leads to a great number of octahedral vacancies, which are beneficial to integrate with various mental cations [32,33]. Meanwhile, a large amount of silanol group form on the surface of sepiolite during the acidic hydrolysis and these surface silanol groups (SiOH) are the main active centers for adsorption [32,34,35]. Many researchers have been studied on the modified sepiolite supported active metal catalysts in hydrogenation or oxidation reaction [36,37]. However, HDN hydrogenation over acid-modified sepiolite supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalyst has not been reported. In this study, different acid-activated sepiolites were used as catalyst support for loading nickel and potassium. The acid-activated sepiolite supported catalysts were investigated in HDN hydrogenation under moderate conditions. It shows high activity and selectivity to ACN and HDA. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Natural sepiolite was obtained from Henan Xinglei Sepiolite Limited Company, 95% content of sepiolite (42.21% SiO2, 20.57% MgO, 18.83% CaO, 0.37% Al2O3, 0.21% Fe2O3, 0.18% K2O, 0.08% Na2O, 0.05% MnO, 0.02% P2O5, 0.017% TiO2, 0.012% FeO and 15.57% Lost on ignition) was obtained by purification. 1,6-Hexanedinitrile (98.5wt.%), 6-aminocapronitrile (98wt.%) and 1,6-hexanediamine (99wt.%) were purchased from J&K scientific LTD. KNO3, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and ethanol were analytical grade and obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Corporation Limited. H2 (99.99%) was obtained from Zhuzhou Diamond Gas Company. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The pre-prepared sepiolite powder (SEP) was washed by deionized water and acidified by nitric acid, hydrochloric acid or sulfuric acid with the solid-to-liquid ratio of 1:15 at 348K under mechanical agitation for 24h. And the mixture was filtered, the precipitate was washed with distilled water and dried at 393K for 3h. The sepiolite treated with nitric acid, hydrochloric acid or sulfuric acid was labeled as NASEP, CASEP, SASEP. During the acid treatment, it can be seen from Scheme 1 that the SiOMgOSi bond in sepiolite transform into two SiOH bonds and the SiOH bonds condense to SiOSi bonds [31,33]. The catalysts were synthesized by the incipient wetness method and through the following steps. Firstly, 5g of acid-activated sepiolite was impregnated in 25mL of an aqueous solution including 49.50mg of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.65mg of KNO3 and stirred for 12h, followed by drying at 393K for 12h, calcining at 623K for 4h in the fluid nitrogen stream, and reducing at 673K for 4h in the flowing hydrogen stream. The prepared catalysts were labeled as Ni/CASEP, K-Ni/CASEP, Ni/NASEP, K-Ni/NASEP, Ni/SASEP and K-Ni/SASEP, respectively. The amount of nickel is 20wt.% and the amount of the potassium is 0.5wt.%, respectively. Scheme 2 illustrates the process of acid treatment and nickel adsorption. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area, pore size distribution and pore volume were measured on Quantachrome NOVA-2200e automated gas sorption system by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption. The specific surface area was calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET). The Barrett- Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was used to analyze the pore volume and pore size distributions. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed on Shimadzu IR Prestige-21 spectrometer with a KBr beam splitter. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) elementary mappings were obtained from an FEI Tecnai G2F30 S-TWIN field emission transmission electron microscope equipped with an EDX spectrometer operating at 300kV. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were recorded by using a D/max 2500 TC diffractometer equipped with a back monochromator operating under the conditions of tube voltage of 40kV, a tube current of 30mA by using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.542Å). The samples were scanned at a rate of 1°min−1 over the range from 5° to 90°. The reducibility of the calcined samples was analyzed by temperature programmed reduction (TPR) on a Quantachrome ChemBET-3000 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a procedure temperature-controlled furnace at the range of 273K–1273K. Firstly, the samples were preheated to 473K for 2h in argon-atmosphere, and then constantly heated from 473K to 1173K at 5Kmin−1 with the existence of 40mLmin−1 5vol.% of H2/Ar flow. Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was performed on the same instrument as that of temperature programmed reduction (TPR). Firstly, the samples were preheated to 523K for 1h in the fluid helium gas atmosphere and cooled to 353K for 30min in the same helium-atmosphere before exposed to a 10 vol.% of NH3/He flow with a rate of 40mLmin−1. The easily adsorbed NH3 was purged by helium flow for 30min until consecutive pulses base line became stable, and then the NH3-TPD was programmed from 353K to 1123K at a rate of 10Kmin−1 in the fluid helium-atmosphere. Hydrogen chemisorption was also carried out on Quantachrome ChemBET-3000. Firstly, the samples were re-reduced by heating in a flow of hydrogen stream at 523K for 12h, and then the system was purged with flowing argon stream to remove the adsorbed hydrogen on the nickel surface and cooled to 303K in the flowing argon stream. The injection of hydrogen pluse size was 0.02mL until consecutive pulses base line became stable. The number of nickel atoms on the surface area was reckoned by assuming the stoichiometric of one hydrogen molecule per two surface nickel atoms. The surface area of nickel was reckoned from the nickel atomic cross-sectional area of a nickel atom of 6.49×10−20 m2/Ni atom. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) micrographs of the samples were observed by a JEOL JSM-6610LV scanning microscope. The SEM composites were firstly dispersed in dilute ethanol on a copperplate, and then evaporated the ethanol at the room temperature. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on JEOL 2010 FEG microscope at 200kV. The samples were dispersed in ethanol by the process of sonicate, and then the suspension was dropped onto amorphous carbon films supported on a copper grid. 2.4 Procedure for the catalytic test The reaction of liquid phase 1,6-Hexanedinitrile (HDN) hydrogenation was actualized as follows: 1,6-Hexanedinitrile (5g), ethanol (50mL), catalysts (1g) were added in a 100mL Teflon-lined autoclave fitted with pressure controller, temperature detector and magnetic stirrer. After being sealed, the reactor was excluded air by using the hydrogen, and then the autoclave was heated to setting temperature and pressure under vigorous stirring. During the experiment, the pressure was maintained constantly at 2MPa, the stirring rate was kept at 1000rpm, and the reaction temperature was at the range of 363K to 373K when the reaction finished, the catalyst was removed through filtration, and then the compositions of sample were determined by GC (Agilent 7820A) on a 30m DB-1701 capillary column and the content of reactants and products were analyzed by internal standard method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalyst It can be seen from Table 1 that the surface area of the acid-activated sepiolite (ASEP) is larger than the original sepiolite (SEP). Since acid activation can unfold the closed cell in the sepiolite, get rid of some impurities and increase the specific surface area and the porosity [32,34]. The surface areas of the sepiolite treated with different acid is in the following order: SASEP<NASEP<CASEP. During acid treatment, it removes Mg2+ situated in its octahedral layer but leaves Si4+ coordinated in its tetrahedral layer and the originally microporous structure transforms into mesoporous one when the sepiolite transforms to amorphous-silica (Si-O-Si) [31,33]. Moreover, the amorphous-silica (SiOSi) has the tendency to condense, so does the surface area decrease. It can be seen from Scheme 1 that SiOMgOSi bond in sepiolite transforms into two SiOH bonds after acid treatment with hydrochloric acid or nitric acid, and the SiOH bond condense to SiOSi bond after acid treatment with sulfuric acid. Furthermore, The BET surface area decreases after the metals are loaded on the support. Fig. S1 in the online version at DOI:http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.10.029 shows the adsorption isotherms curves and BJH pore size distributions of the samples. The samples show type IV isotherms, indicating nitrogen capillary condensation in mesoporous sepiolite structure. All the samples show type H4 hysteresis loops, it indicates the slit-shaped pore structure. The area of the hysteresis loop is related with the number of the pores, the larger area indicates more pores. And the pore volume result in Table 1 also confirmed this. Fig. S1 The morphology and microstructure of the samples are shown in Fig. 1 . It is worthy to note that the original fibrous morphology of sepiolite is kept after acid treatment. Fig. 1(a) shows that sepiolite has a stick-like aggregation made up of lots of fibers. It can be seen from Fig. 1(b–d), that the majority of those fibers were cleaved after acidification. Fig. 1(e and f) indicates that nickel and potassium particles cover on the surface of the support. The FT-IR spectra of SEP, CASEP, NASEP and SASEP are shown in Fig. 2 . The bands at 3437cm−1 correspond to stretching vibrations of silanol groups (SiOH) in the octahedral sheet [38]. The bands around 1021cm−1 which attribute to SiOSi stretching still exist in acid-activated sepiolite [39], it means that the basic structure of sepiolite is not destoryed. The SiOSi vibration band at 1100cm−1 appear obvious shoulder peak in acid-activated sepiolite [40], indicating that the bond angle of SiOSi band in tetrahedral sheet is changed. The reason may be that the Mg2+ in the lattice is replaced by H+. The MgOH bending vibration at 3680cm−1 disappears after acid treatment of nitric acid or sulfuric acid. And the band around 1635cm−1 is ascribed to the bending vibration of OH bond of zeolitic water [41]. The bands at 3437cm−1 and 1645cm−1 are progressively broadened in NASEP, it suggests that considerable proportion of silanol groups form after nitric acid treatment. It can be seen that the band of SiOH (3437cm−1) and OH (1645cm−1) is visibly diminished in SASEP, it indicates that the silanol groups (SiOH) is progressively transformed into amorphous silica (SiOSi) after acid treatment of sulfuric acid. Fig. 3 shows the NH3-TPD plots of the supports. Two NH3 desorption peaks are detected in acid-activated sepiolite in the range of 523–673K and 773–873K, these are corresponding to weak acid sites and strong acid sites respectively. However, sepiolite only shows the desorption peak of weak acid sites. Moreover, it can be seen that the weak acid peaks are significantly shifted toward higher temperature when sepiolite is treated with sulfuric acid. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) pattern of the samples are shown in Fig. S2 in the online version at DOI:http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.10.029. And the signals for Ni and K are well attributed to the active component, the signals for Mg, Si, Ca and O are from sepiolite (Fig. S2(a)). It can be seen from Fig. S2(b–d) (in the online version at DOI:http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.10.029) that the intensities of the Mg peaks decreased significantly after acid treatment. Fig. S2(c) in the online version at DOI:http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.10.029 shows that the peak of Mg is weaked and the peak of Ca is almost vanished after nitric acid treatment. Fig. S2(d) in the online version at DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.10.029 shows that the peaks of Ca and S with strong intensity are present in sepiolite treated with sulfuric acid. Fig. S2(e–g) in the online version at DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.10.029 shows the EDX patterns of acid-activated sepiolite supported K-Ni catalysts and semi-quantitative EDX analysis of the samples are shown in Table 2 . Each datum reported is the average value determined from the three locations on the catalyst surface. A large number of highly active silanol groups (Si-OH) on the surface is helpful to grasp the active component and make them well dispersed. Fig. S2(h) in the online version at DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.10.029 shows the elementoverlay of K-Ni/NASEP, it indicates a homogeneous distribution of the components. Fig. S2(h) shows the elementoverlay of K-Ni/NASEP, it indicates a homogeneous distribution of the components. Fig. S2 The TPR profiles of the unreduced samples are shown in Fig. 4 . It can be seen from Fig. 4 that the sepiolite treated with different acid presents different initial reduction temperature, and the TPR peaks are shifted toward lower temperature when the sepiolite was treated with nitric acid. The order of the initial reduction temperature of the samples are NiO/SASEP>NiO/CASEP>NiO/NASEP. The number of silanol groups (Si-OH) in NASEP increases much more than SASEP and CASEP, and the silanol groups (SiOH) in the sepiolite are helpful to nickel particles adsorption and dispersion. There is a reduction peak around 1110K in NiO/SASEP which is attributed to the reduction peak of CaSO4 [42]. Furthermore, the peak of hydrogen consumption of NiO/ASEP is broader than that of K2O-NiO/ASEP, it means that the reduction rate of NiO/ASEP decreases because of the excessive sintering of nickel oxide particles [27]. This may be the reason that the nickel particle size on Ni/ASEP is larger than that of K-Ni/ASEP. Fig. 5 presents the XRD curves of the samples. The diffraction peak of 2θ angle at 44.0, 52.0, 76.0 are ascribed to nickel and 37.0, 43.0, 62.0 are ascribed to nickel oxide. Table 3 depicts the crystalline phases and crystallite sizes of the samples. The peaks of nickel in Ni/ASEP are more spiculate than those in K-Ni/ASEP, it means that K-Ni/ASEP possess smaller nickel particles. It indicates that doping of potassium is benificial to the dispersion of nickel particles, and this is also testified by the following hydrogen chemisorption results in Table 4 . Some researchers have found that doping of the potassium can effectively inhibits the excessive sintering of nickel during the reduction process [17,18,20,27]. Compared with other catalysts, K-Ni/NASEP has broader diffraction peaks of nickel, and K-Ni/NASEP presents smaller nickel crystallite size. The XRD patterns show that nickel oxide and nickel crystalline phase exist in Ni/CASEP, and the peaks of nickel oxide in K-Ni/CASEP are more spiculate than those in Ni/CASEP, it indicates that nickel oxide is harder to be reduced with the introduction of potassium. Table 4 shows the data of H2 chemisorption. It indicates that the addition of potassium remarkably increase the amount of hydrogen chemisorption. Compared with the results of other catalysts, K-Ni/NASEP presents the largest hydrogen uptake quantity of 50.1μLg−1, the best nickel dispersion of 6.4% and the largest metallic surface of 8.3m2 g−1. Fig. 6 shows the TEM images of the samples. The dark dots represent the nickel nanoparticles on the tube-like acid-activated sepiolite surfaces. As shown in Fig. 6(c) and (f), the nickel nanoparticles in K-Ni/SASEP seriously agglomerate. But nanoparticles of nickel in K-Ni/NASEP (Fig. 6(b) and (e)) and K-Ni/CASEP (Fig. 6(a) and (d)) are well-distributed. The size of the nickel particles are about 40nm in K-Ni/SASEP and 20nm in K-Ni/CASEP, However, they are approximate 10nm in K-Ni/NASEP, it indicates that silanol groups (SiOH) increase through acidic hydrolysis and efficiently decrease the nickel nanoparticle size and improve its distribution. 3.2 Catalytic performance HDN hydrogenation was carried out by using ethanol as solvent over the Ni-based/ASEP catalysts. It can be seen from Scheme 3 that the hydrogenation products consist of 6-aminocapronitrile (ACN), 1,6-hexanediamine (HDA), 1-azacycloheptane (ACH) and C12 compounds [7,9,10,15]. Crystalline Ni-K/α-Al2O3 catalyst presented good activity in HDN hydrogenation [27]. Yet, the nickel amount is as high as 30wt.% and the reaction temperature is as high as 423K. The results of HDN hydrogenation catalyzed by different sepiolite supported catalysts are shown in Table 5 . It shows that CASEP and NASEP supported catalysts present higher selectivity to ACN and HDA, while SASEP supported catalysts show higher selectivity to ACN and ACH. Generally, the conversion of HDN increases while the ACN selectivity decreases evidently with the raise of reaction temperature. Overall, sepiolite supported catalysts doped with potassium possess higher selectivity to ACN and HDA. This means that potassium doped catalysts can effectively inhibit the transimination reactions leading to ACH and C12 by-products. Lanthanum, potassium, chromium, titanium or other dopant agents have been shown great influences on the catalytic performance of nickel supported catalysts in liquid or gas phase hydrogenation of HDN [5,11,17,19,20,27]. Thorpe-Ziegler intramolecular condensation of HDN to 2-aminomethylcyclopentylamine (CC bond formation) is inhibited due to the existence of potassium [10]. It has been reported that the selectivity to aminonitrile increases when dinitriles hydrogenation over Raney Ni was carried out in the reaction medium with the addition of inorganic base [2,21,22]. Some researchers explained that the effect of inorganic base addition by the stabilization of an intramolecular interaction of ACN to an heterocyclic form containing imino form of the CN group, and such cyclic conformation would hinder the aminonitrile re-adsorption, which can further hydrogenate to azacycloheptane-2-amine [10,22,44]. The azacycloheptane-2-amine could be transformed to 1-azacycloheptane (ACH) by the hydrogenation and deamination (Scheme 3). And the alkalinity on catalyst surface increases due to the addition of potassium [11,17,19,20,27], which may impede 1-amino-6-imino-hexane intramolecular condensation to ACH [7,10,15]. Didier et al. prepared the Ni-based catalysts elaborated from lamellar double hydroxide precursors and applied in selective half-hydrogenation of HDN, the HDN conversion is about 70% and the ACN selectivity is 66% under 2.5Mpa H2 pressure and 353K reaction temperature [10]. Compared with the Ni-based acid-activated sepiolite catalyst, the preparation method of the catalyst is complicated. Moreover, it needs a certain amount of H2O and inorganic base (KOH) during the HDN hydrogenation, which can result in serious equipment corrosion and large amount of wastewater. From the characterization results (Figs. 5 and 6, Table 4), we can see that the nickel dispersion is improved with the addition of potassium, and nickel crystallite size decreases as well as the metallic surface area increases. This may be the reason that potassium doped catalysts show higher activity at the same reaction conditions. Table 5 shows that K-Ni/CASEP gives 78.0% HDN conversion, while Ni/CASEP gives 70.4% HDN conversion at 373K. Similarly, K-Ni/SASEP gives 64.8% HDN conversion at 373K and the HDN conversion is only 60.8% over Ni/SASEP at the same reaction conditions. Moreover, the HDN conversion is 92.0% over K-Ni/NASEP and 81.4% over Ni/NASEP at 373K respectively. Nitric acid treated sepiolite supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts present the best catalytic performance, the HDN conversion comes up to 92.0% under moderate reaction conditions of 373K and 2.0MPa, the ACN and HDA selectivity is up to 95.2%. It has been reported that two kinds of adsorption sites exist on the internal and external surface of sepiolite, one is the silanol groups (SiOH) and the other is water molecules integrated with Mg2+ [34,35,43]. And some researchers have found that silanol groups (SiOH) on the surface of sepiolite possess synergistic effect with the active component and it is in favor of its high dispersion [37]. The results of FT-IR spectra indicates that the density of silanol groups (SiOH) increase highly after nitric acid treatment, and the silanol groups on the sepiolite surface might aid in nickel adsorption and dispersion, this may be the reason that K-Ni/NASEP and Ni/NASEP catalysts possess higher catalytic performance. And it can be seen from the spectra of FT-IR that the silanol groups (Si-OH) is progressively transformed into amorphous silica (SiOSi) after sulfuric acid treatment. However, amorphous silica (Si-O-Si) is not beneficial to nickel adsorption and dispersion. The results of TEM and XRD patterns also show that SASEP supported catalysts present larger nickel particles and agglomerate phenomenon. It can be noted that SASEP supported catalysts possess relatively lower conversion of HDN and lower selectivity to ACN and HDA. The reason may be that nickel nanoparticles agglomerate seriously on the surface of the sulfuric acid treated sepiolite. Another reason may be that the formed CaSO4 in SASEP may go against nickel particles adsorption and dispersion. And a certain amount of strong acid sites on Ni/SASEP or K-Ni/SASEP help to generate ACH and C12 by-products, so does the selectivity to ACN and HDA decrease. 3.3 The recycle of the catalysts The stability of K-Ni/NASEP has been tested and the recycling results are shown in Table 6 . When the reaction finished, K-Ni/NASEP was separated through filtration, washed with ethanol repeatedly and then dried at room temperature. The K-Ni/NASEP was re-activated in hydrogen fluid at 673K for 4h. The results in Table 6 indicate that the HDN conversion maintains at 87.4% and selectivity to ACN and HDA keeps at 85.7%. However, the catalytic activity decreases slightly in third runs. Through the apparatus of inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis, the nickel content of the third recycled K-Ni/NASEP indicates that the leaching of the nickel can be neglected. Fig. 7 shows XRD patterns and TEM image of the third recycled K-Ni/NASEP. It can be seen that the diffraction peaks of nickel in the third recycled K-Ni/NASEP is more spiculate than the fresh K-Ni/NASEP, which indicates that larger nickel particles exist in third recycled K-Ni/NASEP, and the TEM image also proves this. The reason may be excessive sintering of the nickel particles during the process of regeneration. 4 Conclusions The sepiolite was treated with different inorganic acids and the acid-activated sepiolites supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts were obtained through incipient wetness method. The prepared catalysts were characterized by various methods such as nitrogen adsorption-desorption, hydrogen chemisorption, ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX). The acid-activated sepiolite supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts were investigated in liquid phase HDN hydrogenation. The products consist of ACN, HDA, ACH and C12. It was revealed that the potassium could increase the alkalinity of the catalyst with the aim of inhibiting the formation of the 1-azacycloheptane (ACH). And the addition of potassium reduces the particle size of nickel and improves its dispersion. Compared with the hydrochloric acid and sulfuric acid, nitric acid treatment increases more silanol groups (SiOH) on the sepiolite surface, which is in favor of nickel particles adsorption and dispersion. The results show that nitric acid activated sepiolite supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts (K-Ni/NASEP) present the best catalytic performance, the HDN conversion is as high as 92.0% under moderate reaction conditions of 373K and 2.0MPa, the selectivity to ACN and HMDA is up to 95.2%. coredata.dc:description: Different inorganic acids were used to activate sepiolite, and the acid-activated sepiolites supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts were prepared. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption, hydrogen chemisorption, ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) were used to characterize the catalysts. The catalytic performance of the acid-activated sepiolite supported K-Ni bimetallic catalysts were investigated in 1,6-hexanedinitrile (HDN) hydrogenation in liquid phase. It was revealed that the potassium could increase the alkalinity of the catalyst with the aim of inhibiting the formation of the 1-azacycloheptane (ACH). And the addition of potassium reduces the particle size of nickel and improves its dispersion. Compared with hydrochloric acid and sulfuric acid, nitric acid treatment increases more silanol groups (SiOH) on the sepiolite surface, which is helpful to nickel particles adsorption and dispersion. Nitric acid activated sepiolite supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts (K-Ni/NASEP) present the best catalytic performance, the conversion of HDN comes up to 92.0% under moderate conditions of lower temperature and pressure, the selectivity to 6-aminocapronitrile (ACN) and 1,6-hexanediamine (HDA) is up to 95.2%.
coredata.dc:title: Improved catalytic performance of acid-activated sepiolite supported nickel and potassium bimetallic catalysts for liquid phase hydrogenation of 1,6-hexanedinitrile
